title: deathfire touch is terrible
body:
it is designed to only be really strong on either hybrid champions or nieche cases of casters like malzahar with single target dots in their kit.

on anyone else, this thing deals like 50 to 70 damage over 1.5 seconds by lategame. its especially terrible on casters with long cooldowns and designed around burst.

how does this even compare to a 20% attack speed buff, and 15% lifesteal on a crit, when crit is thrown around like candy on halloween?


considering that this is the only offensive keystone mastery for casters, this thing needs to get looked at.

Why should the caster masteries not be able to cover every caster between them? Every auto based champion gets a massive sustain and DPS amp in their keystone but mages aren't allowed to have a generally good option? 

Why should we have to make do with "Well, the running away thing is kinda useful!" when ADCs get something that is completely perfect for them?

Because the mage role is much, much more diverse than the marksman role. On one side of the spectrum you have diana, a melee burst mage. On the other side, you have karthus, a typical caster mage. Somewhere in the middle there is azir on a level of his own.

Marksmen auto attack. Some weave spells in between their autos. That's it.

You would need ~10 keystones specifically for mages for there to be something that could satisfy them all.

The Cunning Tree is oriented towards burst damage.  Burst mages typically want Thunderlord's Decree.

The Ferocity Tree is oriented more towards consistent damage.

What about the one down the cunning tree that gives you movement speed if you chunk 30% of an enemy's hp?

The thing with DFT is that the damage is weak, but it is always there. It essentially boosts the damage of every single one of your abilities at all times.

It reminds me a lot of a certain talent Death Knights had in WoW where their death coils would do 10% bonus damage to the enemy over 10 seconds. It is truly a 10% damage boost on one of their most used abilities, for a single point! But because each tick did only 1% of the original coil damage it was often considered by newer DK players to be useless, what good is an ability that ticks for 10 damage when the original shot did 1000? Ignoring the fact that the constant burn adds up to a significant amount over the course of any fight.

So, is DFT necessarily good? I don't know, I don't know if it will end up being worth it as compared to the mobility and utility of other keystones. But don't overlook it because the individual numbers are small, they add up.

I agree, I play a lot of {{champion:8}} and this is the only viable keystone option for Vlad. However, it's incredibly underwhelming. Even at 600 AP, this only does 120 damage over 3 seconds on single target (so if I hit my Q), or 60 damage over 1.5 seconds on my aoe abilities. And this would be late, late game. It's very rare that I would ever get that much AP in a game if at all.

So even in the best case scenario, this is a minor tickle against my opponent while they have options to increase attack speed off crits (along with a 15% heal to go with it).

There are SO MANY AD Keystones - yet AP champions have 1 option, it's incredibly disheartening.
Wait...why not use Grasp of the Undying from the resolve tree?

> [{quoted}](name=Ralanr,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=AEXT5lVA,comment-id=00050001,timestamp=2015-11-12T19:20:01.472+0000)
>
> Wait...why not use Grasp of the Undying from the resolve tree?

1) You'd have to put 18 points into the resolve tree, which means missing out on the 7% magic pen from tier 5 of the ferocity tree. Since I go CDR boots on Vlad the 7% magic pen is pretty important, as I don't really get any magic pen until late game when I can pick up a void staff

2) It's pretty rare in top lane trades to stay in combat for 4 seconds with an enemy champion. It's mostly trades consisting of me getting a Q in, possibly an E. Depends who I am against but they are quick trades almost always.

3) Even in team fights when I will likely be in combat longer than 4 seconds so this keystone may be used, it will only apply to 1 enemy. Deathfire touch may be bad, but at least it will do some damage to all enemies when I use my aoe.

4) As Vlad, depending on your build, your hp is going to be hovering from 3k-3.6k most likely. 3% of 3k is 90, at 108 if you get your hp to 3.6k. Meanwhile, depending on your AP, Deathfire touch will likely be doing ~ 110-120 damage over 3 seconds per single target (So your Q) and 55-60dmg over 1.5 seconds for your aoe (W, E, R). There also appears to be no cooldown on Deathfire touch, so it definitely does more damage than Grasp of the Undying.

5) With the lifesteal/spellvamp already available to Vlad, the 3% Lifesteal isn't all that great or necessary, and as shown previously, does less damage than Deathfire Touch. 

If I were going to look at the Resolve Tree, I might look at the Strength of Ages keystone. But that would only provide 300 HP (Which would give Vlad 7.5AP). 7.5AP wouldn't outdamage either Deathfire Touch or Grasp of the Undying, but at least add a little extra health with some extra damage.

Still, I feel Deathfire Touch is the best option - but compared to keystones available for other champions - it feels incredibly underwhelming.

I don't know why what is basically a Liandry's passive was even considered the best thing to give mages. Liandry's is a super niche item solely because its passive's strength varies wildly based on the kit of the champion in question. Why is that considered a good thing to make the only option for the mage class as a whole when it so clearly benefits a small amount of champions much more than the rest?

I mean I guess standard burst mages can go for Thunderlord's Decree but that thing is a weirdly conditional Luden's with a massive cooldown.
Maybe Riot added more dots for #lcsbigplays. So when a player has 100 HP and some dot on himself, the casters can go "OOOOH WILL HE DIE OR LIVE"
it's a really awful mastery. its op as fuck on brand and malz (brand especially, he's honestly op af), while shit on so many other casters who don't have DoTs
Have you tried the cunning tree.  It's actually a better fit for ap casters than the furiocity tree.

>  [...]terrible on casters with long cooldowns and designed around burst.


So than.. how about NOT taking the DoT-Mastery on Burst-Champs? x'D

Deathfire's Touch and Thunderlord's Decree need to take a hint from each other. Deathfire's Touch needs per-level scaling (for the champs who don't build much AP/AD), and Thunderlord's Decree need a shorter cooldown (or it needs to be really worth only getting one proc in a fight).

Riot hates AP champions, in case you were wondering. :P They nerfed mana regen hard last year, when season 5 started. Then they remove mana pots, nerf the stats of AP items, along with giving them dramatic gold increase compared to ad and tank item. ( +500 for Hourglass is ***insane*** ).

And +500g to BT isn't the equivalent..? 0.o or 200g to BotRK while BotRK is being nerfed by 2% per hit? lol. Come on now. Prices were all very balanced. Only thing that's anti-mage this season is the lack of good keystones, though on malz, Brand, Cass, Morg(Adds quite a lot of unavoidable damage when that Q lands, guaranteed 20% for the Q and another 10% from the W underneath them on top of her huge ratios), and Swain (His E empowers it). 4s of DoT is the equivalent of about 11/30 of your AP, which is about 36.67% of your AP. Swain gets to boost that by 20% with his E to make it into about 44%. His E does 282+96% of his AP at max level E and now you're throwing an extra 44% onto that. With a 500 AP build, that's an extra 220 damage.

DoT mages are happy with this and Zyra can put it to use pretty well with her plants.

With that in mind, Riot already said they were looking at a possible hotfix to Warlord's because it's giving way too much power compared to the other masteries but I agree; it's unfair that AD characters get perfect synergy with their masteries through crit while casters don't have a dedicated AP-scaling keystone. These new masteries benefit AD characters way too much, and far too little to other classes.
